questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding obstetric cholestasis?

choices.text: Pruritus usually develops in the third trimester

questions.solution:
Obstetric cholestasis is a condition in which cholestasis occurs in pregnancy. Serum bilirubin increases very late in the disease and total plasma concentrations rarely exceed 5 mg/dL. 

Hyperbilirubinemia results from the retention of conjugated pigment. 

It is also referred to as recurrent jaundice of pregnancy, cholestatic hepatosis, and icterus gravidarum. There is a significant genetic influence. It may be more common in multifetal pregnancies.

Patients present with pruritus that develops usually during the third trimester, typically involving the palms and soles. It is worse at night. Icterus may also be present.

Disorder

Cholestasis of pregnancy Up to 200 1–5
Acute fatty liver of pregnancy 200–800 4–10
Hepatitis 2000+ 5–20

questions.text: A woman at 34 weeks of gestation presents with severe itching over her palms and soles for 2 weeks. She gives a history of similar complaints in her last pregnancy. On examination, she is icteric. Which of the following is the preferred investigation to diagnose this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture is suggestive of cholestasis in pregnancy. Serum bile acid is the earliest and most consistent parameter to increase in obstetric cholestasis.

Serum cholic acid is preferred compared to serum chenodeoxycholic acid.

Although serum bile acid increases after meals it is still considered an important investigation among women with obstetric cholestasis. This is because serum bile acid levels remain significantly elevated in women with obstetric cholestasis in comparison to pregnant women without it.

questions.text:
A food critic at 32 weeks of gestation presents with nausea and mild right upper abdominal pain. She also gives a history of itching over palms and soles for 2 weeks. On examination, she is icteric. Investigations done are shown below. What is the preferred treatment in this condition?

Bilirubin= 3.5mg/dl

AST= 180 U/L

ALP= 230 U/L
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of obstetric cholestasis. Ursodeoxycholic acid is the drug of choice in obstetric cholestasis.

It relieves pruritus, lowers bile acid and serum enzyme levels (like SGOT, ALP). It may also reduce certain neonatal complications such as preterm birth, fetal distress, and respiratory distress syndrome.

Antihistamines and topical emollients may provide some relief. 

Cholestyramine causes decreased absorption of fat-soluble vitamins, which leads to vitamin K deficiency. Fetal coagulopathy may develop, which may lead to intracranial hemorrhage and stillbirth, and therefore it is not preferred.

Disorder

 AST (SGOT) U/L Bilirubin (mg/dL)
Cholestasis of pregnancy Up to 200 1–5
Acute fatty liver of pregnancy 200–800 4–10
Hepatitis 2000+ 5–20

questions.text:
Which of the following features are not likely to be seen in a patient with acute fatty liver of pregnancy?
  1. Hyperglycemia
  2. Coagulopathy
  3. Hypercholesterolemia
  4. Thrombocytosis
  5. Hypofibrinogenemia
questions.solution:
Hyperglycemia, hypercholesterolemia, and thrombocytosis are not likely to be seen in acute fatty liver of pregnancy (AFLP). 

Clinical features of AFLP include:

  • Persistent nausea and vomiting
  • Progressive jaundice
  • Hypoglycemia
  • Hypertension
  • Proteinuria
  • Edema
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Moderate to severe liver dysfunction - manifested by:
    • Hypofibrinogenemia
    • Hypoalbuminemia
    • Hypocholesterolemia
    • Prolonged clotting time.

questions.text: A woman at 37 weeks of gestation with icterus, nausea, and yellowish discoloration of urine has abnormal liver function tests. She is suspected to have acute fatty liver of pregnancy. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: Occurs due to  heterozygous defect for fatty acid oxidation

questions.solution:
Acute fatty liver of pregnancy (AFLP) is more commonly associated with male fetuses and not female fetuses.

AFLP is a rare, potentially fatal complication also known as acute fatty metamorphosis or acute yellow atrophy. It is more common in the third trimester. It is due to a defect in the long-chain-3-hydroxy acyl-CoA-dehydrogenase (LCHAD) pathway.

It is also associated with:

  • First pregnancy - uncommon in subsequent pregnancies
  • Maternal obesity
  • Multiple pregnancies

Investigations:

  • Liver function tests such as AST, ALT, and serum bilirubin levels are raised.
  • Hemolysis with coagulopathy:
    • Decreased platelets and fibrinogen
    • Elevated d-dimers and prothrombin time
  • Biopsy reveals a characteristic microvesicular fatty infiltration.

The definitive management of AFLP is rapid delivery of the fetus and supportive care. Hepatic dysfunction usually normalizes within a week of delivery.

questions.text: Which of the following will not increase the risk for urinary tract infection in pregnant women?
questions.solution:
Hypertension is not a risk factor for urinary infections in pregnancy. 

Risk factors for urinary infections in pregnancy include:

  • Urinary retention
  • Vesicoureteric reflux of pregnancy
  • Diabetes in pregnancy
  • Sickle cell anemia

questions.text:
A G3P2 lady at 13 weeks of gestation presented for a regular antenatal checkup. A urine routine revealed the presence of 2,00,000 gram-negative bacilli/mL. Repeat urinalysis showed the following results. Which of the following is not true about this condition?

Urinalysis:

  • Protein: negative
  • Pus cells: 1-2/HPF
  • Bacteria: 1,50,000 gram negative bacilli/mL

choices.text: Incidence is similar to that in non pregnant women
It is higher in people with sickle cell trait
Antibiotic therapy is required only if symptoms develop
There is risk of developing chronic renal lesions

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of asymptomatic bacteriuria. Antibiotic therapy should be given regardless of the symptoms. 

Asymptomatic bacteriuria refers to persistent, actively multiplying bacteria within the urinary tract in asymptomatic women.

Organisms that cause urinary infections are those from the normal perineal flora. The most common causative agent is E.coli. Others include Klebsiella, and Proteus.

Incidence is similar to that in non-pregnant women. Prevalence depends on parity (more in higher parity), race, socioeconomic status (more in low SES).

It is more common in patients with sickle cell anemia/trait, diabetes. There is a high risk of developing chronic renal lesions in later life. 

It is also associated with:

  • Hypertension
  • Anemia
  • Premature labor
  • Intrauterine growth retardation
  • Urinary tract abnormalities in recurrent cases.

Diagnostic criteria:

  • A positive bacterial count of the same species - over 1,00,000/mL
  • Organisms in midstream clean-catch specimen of urine on two occasions
  • No symptoms of urinary infection

Treatment:

  • Single-dose therapy - Amoxicillin 3g, Nitrofurantoin 200mg 
  • Regular 10-14 days therapy - Amoxicillin, Nitrofurantoin, Cephalexin, or Amoxiclav
  • Recurrent cases need to be treated until delivery with prophylactic doses.

questions.text: A woman presented to the clinic with severe lower abdominal pain and dysuria at 28 weeks of gestation.  Suprapubic tenderness was noted on palpation. Urine examination revealed pyuria with microscopic hematuria.  All of the following can be used to treat this condition except?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cystitis. Ciprofloxacin, a fluoroquinolone antibiotic, is contraindicated in pregnancy as it causes cartilage and bone defects in the fetus.

Antibiotics are used for treating cystitis in pregnancy. 

Antibiotics safe in pregnancy include:

  • Penicillin group
  • Cephalosporins
  • Erythromycin
  • Metronidazole (except in the 1st trimester)

Antibiotics unsafe in pregnancy include:

  • Tetracycline
  • Aminoglycoside
  • Chloramphenicol
  • Metronidazole(in the first trimester)
  • Fluoroquinolones

questions.text: Which stage of pregnancy is most often complicated by acute pyelonephritis?
questions.solution:
Acute pyelonephritis in pregnancy most often complicates 2nd trimester of pregnancy. 

Acute pyelonephritis occurs more commonly in those with preexisting renal disease. It is caused by E. coli >> Streptococcus sp., S.aureus > Enterobacter, Klebsiella sp. 

Clinical features include:

  • Fever with chills
  • Loin pain
  • Vomiting
  • Right-sided renal angle tenderness

Patients may develop acute respiratory distress syndrome due to endotoxin-mediated alveolar injury. Hemolysis can also occur due to endotoxins, leading to anemia.

Treatment includes intravenous fluids with antibiotics.

questions.text: Which of the following congenital infections are associated with the triad of Gregg in a neonate?
questions.solution:
Triad of Gregg is seen in a neonate infected congenitally with rubella virus. The features include:

  • Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA)
  • Cataract
  • Sensorineural Hearing loss (SNHL)

Other infections which cause congenital malformations are:

Organism Effect
Toxoplasma

Hydro/microcephaly, convulsions, chorioretinitis, cerebral calcification
Varicella

Skin scarring, hypoplastic limbs, eye defects, microcephaly
Parvovirus Non-immune hydrops
Syphilis

Hutchinson's triad: 

  • Interstitial keratitis
  • Hutchinson's teeth
  • Eighth nerve deafness

Related Pearl: Rubella and congenital rubella syndrome

Congenital rubella syndrome:

  • The triad of Gregg in congenital rubella syndrome includes:
    • Sensorineural hearing loss - Nerve deafness is the single most common finding among infants with congenital rubella syndrome
    • Congenital cataract
    • Congenital heart disease - The most common cardiac defect is patent ductus arteriosus
  • Maximum damage to the fetus occurs in the first trimester
  • Infection in the second trimester causes only deafness
  • If infection occurs after 16 weeks there are no major abnormalities
  • Diagnosis - Presence of IgM rubella antibodies in the infant shortly after birth or persistence of IgG antibodies for >6 months.

The given image shows bilateral cataract in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The given image shows blueberry muffin rash in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The image given below shows the salt and pepper fundus.

 Rubella:

  • Also called the German measles
  • Causative organism belongs to the family Matonaviridae
  • Period of infectivity is -5 to +6 days after the onset of the rash
  • Droplet trasmission
  • The incubation period is 2-3 weeks
  • The rash appears on day 1
  • Forchheimer spots are seen, which are tiny, rose-colored lesions in the oropharynx
  • Associated with post-infectious thrombocytopenia
  • The most serious complication is encephalitis
  • Vaccination is done with the live attenuated RA 27/3 strain of the rubella

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about toxoplasmosis in pregnancy?

choices.text: Maximum transmission and damage in 1st trimester
Maximum transmission in 1st trimester and maximum damage in 3rd trimester
Maximum damage in 1st trimester and maximum transmission in 3rd trimester
Maximum transmission and damage in 3rd trimester

questions.solution:
Toxoplasmosis causes maximal complications in 1st trimester and is maximally transmitted in the 3rd trimester.

This is because the risk of transmission increases and the risk of damage decreases as pregnancy progresses further.

Clinical features of affected neonates include:

  • Hydrocephalus or microcephaly
  • Chorioretinitis
  • Intracranial calcifications
  • Convulsions
  • Low birthweight
  • Hepatosplenomegaly
  • Jaundice
  • Anemia

questions.text: A woman presents for a regular antenatal check-up at 12 weeks of gestation. She works at a rescue center that held an adoption drive for cats a few weeks ago. On examination, mild cervical lymphadenopathy is noted. Sabin-Feldman dye test is positive. Which of the following will be used to treat this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario points to a diagnosis of maternal toxoplasmosis. It is treated using spiramycin.

Pyrimethamine-sulfonamide is used when fetal infections are confirmed. It should be avoided in the first trimester.

Toxoplasmosis is caused by Toxoplasma gondii. Cats are definitive hosts. It can be transmitted to humans either by ingestion of raw or inadequately cooked infected meat or by ingestion of oocysts via exposure to cat litter or soil.

Acute infection is diagnosed either by the presence of IgG and IgM antibodies or by a four-fold increase in paired specimens 4 weeks apart.

questions.text: A per-vaginal examination performed on a lady in labor reveals multiple painful tiny vesicular ulcers over the vulva and vaginal walls. A slide showing the microscopic findings is given below. What is the best step in the management of delivery in this patient?

choices.text: Give tocolytics and treat the infection

questions.solution:
Painful genital ulcers and painful inguinal lymphadenopathy are suggestive of herpes virus infection. The cytological image showing multinucleate giant cells, Tzanck cells confirms the diagnosis of HSV. The best step in the management of delivery in this patient is a cesarean section. 

Herpes infection in the newborn may occur during birth, particularly if the mother has genital lesions due to HSV-2. In such cases, a cesarean section may prevent neonatal infection.

questions.text: In a pregnant woman with herpes simplex infection, the risk of transmission to the fetus will be maximum during which stage of the pregnancy?
questions.solution:
The maximum risk of HSV transmission from mother to child is during labor. This is due to the shedding of the virus from an active infection in the genital tract during delivery.

HSV is a sexually transmitted infection. There is a higher risk of transmission during primary infections than with recurrences. Reactivations are less severe.

Cesarean delivery reduces the risk of vertical transmission during labor and is indicated in:

  • Cases of active genital lesions - both primary and recurrent
  • Prodromal symptoms - like vulval itching or burning

Suspicious lesions should be sent for PCR testing or culture. Antiviral treatment with acyclovir should be given if found positive.

Women without active genital lesions, without symptoms, or those with active lesions in non-genital areas can undergo normal labor and delivery. 

Management of HSV infection during pregnancy:

  • Primary or recurrent infections during pregnancy - Oral acyclovir or valacyclovir
  • Severe or disseminated infection - IV acyclovir followed by oral acyclovir
  • Pain relief - Oral analgesics or topical anesthetics
  • Urinary retention - catheterization.

questions.text: The risk of fetal varicella syndrome is maximum when the mother is infected between _____.
questions.solution:
The risk of developing fetal varicella syndrome (congenital varicella syndrome) is highest when the mother develops varicella infection between 13 to 20 weeks. 

Congenital varicella syndrome occurs in 2% of infants with maternal varicella between 13 and 20 weeks of gestation and in 0.4% of infants before 13 weeks of gestation. It is rare after 20 weeks.

Congenital varicella syndrome is characterized by cicatricial skin scarring in a zoster-like pattern (zig-zag scarring), and limb hypoplasia (shown below). They can also present with neurological abnormalities (microcephaly, cortical atrophy, mental retardation), ophthalmic features (chorioretinitis, microphthalmia, cataract), and renal and autonomic system abnormalities (hydronephrosis, neurogenic bladder). Low birth weight is also common. 

Infants born to mothers with varicella in the period from 5 days prior to delivery up to 2 days after delivery are at high risk for severe neonatal varicella. They acquire the infection transplacentally.

Since the mother has not developed a strong antibody response, the infant lacks the protective effect of maternal anti-varicella-zoster virus (VZV) antibodies.  Therefore varicella-zoster immune globulin (VZIG) should be administered as soon as possible after birth to newborns whose mothers have varicella 5 days before and up to 2 days after the delivery. 

Since perinatally acquired varicella can be potentially life-threatening, the infant should typically be treated with intravenous acyclovir (10 mg/kg every 8 hours) when lesions appear. 

For pregnant women with uncomplicated primary varicella or herpes zoster that does not require hospitalization, the recommended treatment is oral acyclovir (800 mg five times daily for seven days).

questions.text: A young woman delivered a baby with limb hypoplasia and cicatricial skin lesions. Which of the following infections did the mother most likely have during her pregnancy?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of congenital varicella syndrome. It is seen in babies born to mothers who had chickenpox infections during their pregnancy.

Features of congenital varicella syndrome include:

  • Chorioretinitis
  • Limb hypoplasia
  • Cicatricial skin lesions
  • Microphthalmia
  • Cerebral cortical atrophy
  • Growth restriction
  • Hydronephrosis

questions.text: In a pregnant woman with syphilis, the infection can get transmitted to the fetus during which stage in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
A pregnant woman with syphilis can transmit T. pallidum to the fetus at 10–15 weeks of gestation.

Features of congenital syphilis include:

  1. Hutchinson's triad - It is seen in late congenital syphilis.
    • Hutchinson’s teeth - small widely spaced, peg-shaped, notched upper incisors
    • Interstitial keratitis
    • Sensorineural hearing loss
  2. Mulberry molars
  3. Rhagades - deep fissuring of mucocutaneous junctions in the nares, lips, and anus
  4. Frontal bossing
  5. Saber shins - anterior tibial bowing
  6. Clutton’s joints - painless, symmetric hydrarthrosis of the knees and elbows

 The image below shows Hutchinson incisors.

Note: The risk of fetal infection during untreated early maternal syphilis is ~75–95%, decreasing to ~35% for maternal syphilis of >2 years duration.

questions.text: You are posted in the labor room. While inspecting the placenta to rule out any abnormalities, you notice that it appears pale and enlarged. Which of the following infections does the mother most likely have?
questions.solution:
Enlarged and pale placenta is due to infection by syphilis.

Other clinical manifestations and complications include:

  • Spontaneous abortion
  • Stillbirth
  • Non-immune hydrops 
  • Intrauterine growth restriction 
  • Perinatal death.

questions.text: A sexually active woman presents with amenorrhea for the past 3 months and a history of a painless genital ulcer. UPT is positive and routine antenatal tests revealed a reactive VDRL report. What is the dose of benzathine penicillin that should be given for this patient?

choices.text: 2.4 million units intramuscularly as a single injection
2.4 million units intramuscularly daily, plus probenecid 500 mg orally for 14 days
2.4 million units intramuscularly weekly for three doses

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of early syphilis in a pregnant woman. 2.4 million units of benzathine penicillin should be given intramuscularly as a single injection.

Treatment of syphilis includes:

  • Early syphilis - Benzathine penicillin G, 2.4 million units intramuscularly as a single injection
  • Late syphilis (>1 year duration) - Benzathine penicillin G, 2.4 million units intramuscularly weekly for three doses

Treatment of neurosyphilis:

  • Aqueous crystalline penicillin G, 3–4 million units intravenously every 4 hours for 10–14 days
  • Procaine penicillin, 2.4 million units intramuscularly daily, plus probenecid 500 mg orally four times daily, both for 10–14 days.

questions.text: A woman at 24 weeks of gestation presented with complaints of fatigue, joint pain, and the following rash for 3 weeks. Urinalysis showed proteinuria and anti-Smith antibodies were positive. Which of the following complications is least likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
The above scenario points to a diagnosis of SLE. Preterm labor is a complication in pregnant women with SLE, not post-term delivery.

Complications in a pregnant patient with SLE include:

  • Thrombophilia
  • Preterm labor
  • Hypertension, eclampsia, and preeclampsia
  • Anemia
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Stroke
  • Renal failure

Features of neonatal lupus include:

  • Cardiac abnormalities - Complete heart blocks 
  • Cutaneous lupus
  • Hepatobiliary diseases - liver failure, transient conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, transient transaminase elevations
  • Hematologic abnormalities - thrombocytopenia, neutropenia, or anemia

questions.text: A woman with HIV presents for a routine antenatal checkup at 35 weeks of gestation. Investigations revealed a viral load of >1000 copies/ml. What will be the best mode of delivery in this patient?
questions.solution:
Cesarean delivery is the preferred mode of delivery in a woman with HIV viral load above 1000 copies/ml at 34-36 weeks of gestation.

Cesarean delivery is usually scheduled at 38 weeks of gestation, or two weeks before the due date.

Pregnant women with HIV on ART throughout pregnancy, with a viral load <1000 copies/mL evaluated within 4-6 weeks of delivery, may choose to have a vaginal delivery.

questions.text: A woman is diagnosed to be positive for HIV in her first trimester. What is the appropriate management?

choices.text: Start ART immediately and continue till 6 weeks after delivery
Start ART after 1st trimester and continue life-long
Start ART immediately and continue life-long
Start ART after 1st trimester and continue till 6 weeks after delivery

questions.solution:
ART should be initiated immediately and continued lifelong in all pregnant and breastfeeding women with HIV. This is regardless of their WHO clinical stage and CD4 cell count.

*Note: Pearl attached below has been updated according to the NACO ART guidelines 2021. Efavirenz has been replaced by Dolutegravir as per the new guidelines.

Related Pearl: NACO ART Guidelines- 2021

ART regimen

First-line for:

Tenofovir + Lamivudine + Dolutegravir
  • All PLHIV who are age >10 years and body weight >30 kg with HIV-1, HIV-2, HIV 1&2 co-infection who have not received any ART 
  • Those with HIV-TB and HIV hepatitis co-infections
  • Pregnant women, pregnant women presenting in active labour and breastfeeding women

Abacavir + Lamivudine + Efavirenz
  • All PLHIV with abnormal serum creatinine values 
  • All PLHIV with bodyweight less <30 kg

Tenofovir + Lamivudine + Efavirenz /Lopinavir /Ritonavir
  • Women of childbearing age group who do not wish to take Dolutegravir
  • All PLHIV who were on the previous recommended regime (Tenofovir+Lamivudine+Efavirenz) to be counselled to switch to new regime. Continue older regime if response is good
  • Women in child-bearing age group to be counselled about Dolutegravir with opt-out option before switching to new regime

*PLHIV: People living with HIV

Related Pearl: Prevention of parent to child transmission (PPTCT)

Important provisions of PPTCT services for HIV:

  • HIV counseling and testing for all pregnant women enrolled in antenatal care with ‘opt out’ option.
  • Lifelong ART i.e. Tenofovir (TDF) + Lamivudine (3TC)+ Dolutegravir (DTG) administration to all pregnant and breastfeeding HIV-infected women regardless of CD4 count and clinical stage.
  • Institutional deliveries of HIV-infected mothers
  • Care of associated conditions (STI/RTI, TB, opportunistic infections, hypertension, diabetes)
  • Exclusive breastfeeding counseling
  • Plasma viral load testing at 32–36 weeks of gestation to determine the risk of HIV transmission to the baby
  • Initiation of ARV in babies:
    • Low-risk infants: Syrup Nevirapine from birth till 6 weeks of age
    • High-risk infants: Syrup Nevirapine+ syrup Zidovudine either from birth till 6 weeks of age (exclusive replacement feeding) or from birth till 12 weeks of age (exclusive breastfeeding)
  • Nutrition counseling and psychosocial support to HIV-infected pregnant women
  • Ensure co-trimoxazole prophylactic therapy (CPT) and early infant diagnosis using HIV-DNA PCR at 6 weeks of age onwards as per guidelines

questions.text: A woman with HIV on antiretroviral therapy is in labor. Which of the following will be given to her newborn baby prophylactically?

choices.text: 12 weeks of zidovudine, nevirapine and lamivudine

questions.solution:
In India, according to the NACO guidelines, nevirapine is given in the syrup form for 6 weeks to an infant of a mother who is on long-term ART.

In infants born to mothers with HIV who are not on ART, syrup nevirapine should be continued for 12 weeks. 

According to the NIH guidelines, zidovudine should be given to the neonate for 4 weeks.

questions.text: The risk of developing a stroke is highest during what period of gestation in a pregnant woman?
questions.solution:
The highest incidence of stroke in pregnancy is 5 days to 2 weeks postpartum. This is followed by the intrapartum period.

There is an increased risk of cerebrovascular thrombosis post-delivery due to a sudden reduction in the blood volume, a fall in the level of circulating antithrombotic factors, and venous stasis.

Risk factors of stroke in pregnancy include:

  • Hypertensive disorders
  • Gestational diabetes
  • Antepartum hemorrhage
  • Cesarean delivery.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding epilepsy in pregnancy?

choices.text: It increases risk of fetal malformations by 5%
Seizure risk is more at the time of delivery
Seizure frequency increases in 30% of women
Ideal contraceptive in breast feeding mother with seizure disorder is DMPA

questions.solution:
Untreated epilepsy has no association with fetal malformations. Anti-epileptic medications such as valproate, phenytoin, etc., are responsible for fetal malformations.

Seizure frequency is unchanged in 50%, increased in 30%, and decreased in 20% women.

Seizure risk increases during labor as pain and hyperventilation decrease the seizure threshold.

The ideal contraceptive in a breastfeeding mother with a seizure disorder is depot medroxyprogesterone acetate (DMPA), as progestins increase the seizure threshold.
